body: https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/13025442/0001-NIFI-8519-Support-RequiresInstanceClassLoading-annot.patch is the patch that I attached.
One last thing that I think is necessary: please make sure that the admin guide is updated to describe the new properties.
@patricker - any chance you can rebase this against main/latest?

> Great work, this has a nice feel to it when you put it all together! Just documentation comments below. Also, we should update the Getting Started guide, which still references localhost:8080.

Thanks for the feedback @gresockj!  I pushed an update with additional details in the Getting Started guide describing the generated credentials and referencing to new default URL.
+1 LGTM, ran various flows using some affected processors, everything looks good. Thanks for the upgrade! Merging to main
Thanks for the thorough review and helpful feedback @gresockj!  I added a commit including the changes and rebased on main to incorporate recent updates.
+1 LGTM, verified the system tests and stateless flow with SplitText work as expected. Thanks for the fix! Merging to main
Reviewing...
Thanks @simonbence ! All looks good now. Fixed one checkstyle violation but all was good otherwise. +1 merged to main!
Thanks @mattyb149 looks good to me +1 merged to main
Haven't tried it to confirm, but I don't think this will work with the Docker start scripts, which still default to no authentication (or is that a conscious decision)?

> Haven't tried it to confirm, but I don't think this will work with the Docker start scripts, which still default to no authentication (or is that a conscious decision)?

Thanks for the feedback @ChrisSamo632, that's a good question.  The change to the default properties will impact the Docker image.  It looks like some adjustments to the startup property configuration in the Docker image is going to be necessary.  I will look into it and evaluate potential changes.

I checked the Accumulo page for release notes on this and checked the commits for the 2.0.1 tag, looks like there shouldn't be any compatibility issues with this patch version (as we'd expect). Do you foresee any issues with this upgrade? I ran the ScanAccumuloIT which passed just fine.
Will review

> I checked the Accumulo page for release notes on this and checked the commits for the 2.0.1 tag, looks like there shouldn't be any compatibility issues with this patch version (as we'd expect). Do you foresee any issues with this upgrade? I ran the ScanAccumuloIT which passed just fine.

Thanks for checking @thenatog.  I also reviewed the release notes and changes from 2.0.0 and 2.0.1.  The changes primarily related to Accumulo server, so I don't see any concerns with upgrading versions.

Thanks for the updates, especially the Variable Registry.
LGTM

@thenatog and @exceptionfactory  I haven't tested this bundle with the updated pom specifically but have tested 2.0.1 -> 2.0.0 and there should be no issues previously. The only possible concern would be Thrift interconnect changes but the API was not changed in that patch release. The changes made [1] are within a thrift server implementation for better exception management and as @exceptionfactory suggested, not particularly pertinent to this bundle [0] . I would have no heartburn merging this . 

Would you both feel more confident if I tried to find some time to test this? I have a queue of various PRs that I'm trying to test across various projects  -- so I'd likely not be able to get to it until the end of the week; however, since this is so minor I can probably get to it sooner. 

[0] https://github.com/apache/accumulo/compare/rel/2.0.0...rel/2.0.1#diff-ca2a04249ba6f604c36af23d96e2c3949e6098223a6b7cffea8ea299f1644095R149
[1] https://github.com/apache/accumulo/compare/rel/2.0.0...rel/2.0.1

Thanks for the feedback @phrocker!  Given the apparent low impact of the changes from 2.0.0 from 2.0.1, I'm comfortable moving forward, however, I defer to you and @thenatog to decide whether additional verification is necessary.  The version upgrade isn't pressing from my perspective, so there is time for additional verification if either of you think it is worth spending the cycles.
Reviewing

Tested this out and seems to work well. One question would be, why specifically is the default port 9443? Typically, most documentation refers to NiFi using 8443 for secure NiFi:
https://pierrevillard.com/2016/11/29/apache-nifi-1-1-0-secured-cluster-setup/
https://community.cloudera.com/t5/Community-Articles/Securing-NiFi-Step-by-Step/ta-p/244315
https://community.cloudera.com/t5/Support-Questions/NiFi-Cannot-replicate-request-to-Node-nifi-domain-net-8443/td-p/283664
I will test this out with a 3 node cluster

> Tested this out and seems to work well. One question would be, why specifically is the default port 9443? Typically, most documentation refers to NiFi using 8443 for secure NiFi:
> https://pierrevillard.com/2016/11/29/apache-nifi-1-1-0-secured-cluster-setup/
> https://community.cloudera.com/t5/Community-Articles/Securing-NiFi-Step-by-Step/ta-p/244315
> https://community.cloudera.com/t5/Support-Questions/NiFi-Cannot-replicate-request-to-Node-nifi-domain-net-8443/td-p/283664

Thanks for the testing and feedback @thenatog!  The Administration Guide had a note about 9443 being the default for HTTPS, but this seems like a good opportunity to bring that in line with other common examples, so I will update the default value and documentation to use `8443`.

I am in the process of making some adjustments to the Docker scripts to enable HTTPS by default, so I will push these updates soon.
Hmm, yes, it does appear to be a bit of a mix between 8443 and 9443. Perhaps we should continue with 9443 as that's what officially existed in docs.

> The design looks simple enough, and I like the change to use ClusterNodeFirewall interface in the type parameter. Ran a quick test and verified that the default configuration starts as expected. LGTM!

Thanks for the review @gresockj!
On further assessment, lets use port 8443 rather than 9443.
@phrocker I'm also comfortable merging this one in as is, given the commit log for this version is short and specific to fixes only. Hope you're doing well man!
@milanchandna Thanks for the work on this. It helped inform the completed feature in #2158 #4438 but being that those are done I'm closing this.

@gresockj thanks for all the review feedback! Now that I haven't looked at my code in a while I did start refresh giving myself a full code review. I think everything looked good except that I found a situation in which the State Manager could be updated in stateless even when a downstream processor throw an Exception. I created a system test to verify it, and then I fixed that. You mind giving the latest commit a once-over also?

Thank you @JonathanKessler! This is a great improvement. I can also see a future improvement that would be great where we could use this information in the Status page in order to sort queues by the Average Queue Time, etc. so that it will help to determine where bottlenecks may be in the flow, etc.

The only issue I had with the update was the verbiage used in the ConnectionStatusDescriptor (these stats are not related to the last 5 minutes). So I tweaked the descriptions there, changed the type of Max Queued Duration to DURATION instead of COUNT. Also added in the Average in addition to the max, so that it's provided in the NiFi UI (this won't be shown in the Connection Status, etc. only in the UI).

Otherwise, all looks really good. This was a very non-trivial improvement, and I appreciate you sticking with us to get everything sorted. Great contribution, thanks again!

+1 LGTM, tested with a secure cluster, verified startup was successful, I believe the Github Actions failures are either Java 11 related or otherwise separate from this PR. Thanks for the fix! Merging to main
Request to the wrong NiFi branch

Thanks @gresockj. I've seen no other reviews and no objections anywhere. After putting it away for a few weeks I came back and did a thorough code review myself as well. And the Github Actions failure was due to a failure pulling a dependency, which is unrelated; the other two passed. Based on all of that I'll go ahead and merge to `main`. Thanks for the thorough reviews @gresockj !

Thanks for your contribution @phuthientran.  As noted in the checklist, all pull requests must meet several minimum criteria for consideration.  In particular, a [Jira issue](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI) must be created for tracking the changes, and the initial PR submission must have all commits squashed into a single commit.  Following those steps will help reviewers evaluate your proposed changes.

As mentioned in the [Contributor Guide](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/NIFI/Contributor+Guide#ContributorGuide-FindingIssuesandExtendingtheProject), joining the developers mailing list and requesting Jira contributor access will also allow you to assign the issue to yourself and mark it as Patch Available when it is linked to your PR.
Happy to contribute, thank you for the guidance!
Thank you @exceptionfactory for the detailed review. All suggestions pointed out looks good, will work on changing them..

Tested this out on a 3 node cluster without the fix, identified the issue as stated. Attached is a screenshot of what it looked like for me - files stuck in the queue, and the UpdateAttribute processor did not appear to see the files. Also a queue listing says the queue has no files as shown in the screenshot. 
![Screen Shot 2021-05-19 at 1 06 05 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38888042/118860037-e9b67f00-b8a8-11eb-891f-5f008c841bd2.png)
I then built with this PR, retested and found the issue was resolved.
+1 will merge

Thanks for the review @gresockj . Not sure that we really need to encourage developers to use it, to be honest. I created the unit test to verify that the changes that I was going to make would in fact result in better performance. And I figured it may be useful to me and others in the future so I left it. Is intended to simply be a tool to aid in that process when desirable.
@mattyb149 great, let me know if you have any comments or proposed changes.

https://github.com/greyp9/nifi/tree/NIFI-8621-A

check for correct linking

Hi @matthew-formosa-gig - I know this is an old one, but happy to spend some cycles on this if you want to get this in. I tried to give the PR a try by running a local ignite instance on Docker but could not send any data in it and I noticed quite a lot of exceptions on the NiFi side. Also when you want to test the thin client, you need to define a cache name, any guidance on how to set this into the Docker container?
+1 LGTM, reviewed the code and ran a flow from the stateless assembly (vs the nifi.sh stateless from the top-level) successfully. Thanks for the improvements! Merging to main

CI failed, but seems not related to the PR

LGTM+1

Merged to main.

@timeabarna  Sorry I meant to reply to say that all was good with testing. I lost track of time, but after seeing @tpalfy 's merge, I am happy to add that I didn't encounter issues during testing. Thanks!

I was able to set aside a few hours late last Friday and simply forgot to respond. My apologies for being scatter-brained.
@phrocker No worries. Thank you very much for your help. Your feedback and time are much appreciated.
+1 merging :)

Thanks @exceptionfactory. This appears to work as designed. However, I think that this is a pretty concerning change to the user experience. Every time the user wants to login, they now are required to go find that generated username and password. There appears to be no way to set your own. I think we need the ability to set the username & password somehow. Preferably with something like `nifi.sh set-single-user <user> <pass>` or something like that.

Would also recommend using a pre-defined username such as `admin` or `nifi` or something but I can leave that up to your discretion if the commandline util gives us the ability to set username and password
+1 LGTM, tested on a live flow, verified a string array in the record was successfully inserted into Cassandra. Thanks for the improvement! Merging to main

> Thanks @exceptionfactory. This appears to work as designed. However, I think that this is a pretty concerning change to the user experience. Every time the user wants to login, they now are required to go find that generated username and password. There appears to be no way to set your own. I think we need the ability to set the username & password somehow. Preferably with something like `nifi.sh set-single-user <user> <pass>` or something like that.
> 
> Would also recommend using a pre-defined username such as `admin` or `nifi` or something but I can leave that up to your discretion if the commandline util gives us the ability to set username and password

Thanks for the review and feedback @markap14!  Although Single User authentication is not intended for production use cases, having the ability to change the credentials would certainly make it easier to get started.

I pushed an update that includes a new command option:

`nifi.sh set-single-user-credentials <username> <password>`

This required refactoring shared classes to a new `nifi-single-user-utils` module that could be leveraged in the bootstrap library.  I also updated the Getting Started documentation with an example command, and included a log statement with the command after generating the default random credentials.

With this option, I kept the random username as well as random password.

Please let me know if you have any additional feedback.
Testing this out

> Functions as designed, just a couple documentation changes needed.

Thanks for the additional feedback @gresockj!

Looks good to me, tested this out with Java 8 OpenJDK jdk1.8.0_172 and did not see TLS v1.3 as an option in StandardRestrictedSSLContextService. Then tried Java 8 OpenJDK jdk1.8.0_261 and was able to select TLS v1.3. Also tried AdoptOpenJDK 1.8.0_265 and was able to select TLS v1.3. +1 will merge.
Good catch @kevdoran, I would agree that we should get rid of the husky hooks. Looks there are a couple of conflicts that need to be cleaned up as well. I'd be a +1 otherwise, as well.
Reviewing. These are almost all test usages but there is an instance in nifi-dbcp-service as an in-mem DB option
+1 LGTM, verified with the embedded Derby DB with PutDatabaseRecord and PutSQL. Thanks for the improvement! Merging to main
Thanks @s9514171 I am a +1!

Tested this out using the template found here: https://community.cloudera.com/t5/Community-Articles/NiFi-Send-to-syslog/ta-p/248638 and found that PutSyslog and ListenSyslog are working. Reviewed the code and it looks good.
Thank you @mattyb149 for the quick review and merge.
@gresockj thanks for your help, I've modified the code based on your recommendations.
Thanks @scottyaslan. I also open another JIRA [https://github.com/apache/nifi/pull/5097](https://github.com/apache/nifi/pull/5097) for the issue variable count not reset in variable registry dialog.

@adenes Thanks for the review.

Merging to main.
@jfrazee Hello Joey, file upload with renaming has been created. When you have some time can you please check? Thanks in advance for your help.

Thank you for approving, @gresockj ! I did not measure the difference in performance. I assume that creating a new instance of a GenericRecord type has some overhead. The other type inheriting from AvroRecordReader (AvroReaderWithEmbeddedSchema) has been using this approach for years ( https://github.com/apache/nifi/blob/7fe8858d22f580ad9dcd96ebafb59dbe5e73f5cb/nifi-nar-bundles/nifi-standard-services/nifi-record-serialization-services-bundle/nifi-record-serialization-services/src/main/java/org/apache/nifi/avro/AvroReaderWithEmbeddedSchema.java#L53 ).

@kevdoran, @markap14  I agree, the Husky hooks should be opt-in.
That being said I'd rather have that done as a separate issue. I consider the change non-trivial that needs to be tested and confirmed by devs who have some experience with Husky. (I have not unfortunately.) Better not tie to this one imo.

Based on @tpalfy comment I have changed the place of formatting messages to SimpleProcessLogger in order to avoid branching in LoggingRepository. (The exception messages differs based on they are created by the framework or logged directly.)
+1 will merge.
Thanks @exceptionfactory this looks good. Ran system tests and saw that they are now successful whereas the cluster-based ones previously were failing. +1 merged to main
Thanks @tpalfy for merging these! And thanks to @exceptionfactory and @kevdoran for the review & feedback provided also. I agree with you both that things look good now and I'm a +1. Merged to main!
Thanks for reviewing @exceptionfactory!

I apologize for the late reply, the last months were quite busy and then it took me some time to find out why I didn't replicate the CI test results on my window (some issues with long path, env vars, deps download that fail or tests that failed because the language of my computed isn't english). Well in the end I switched to a another computer with Linux that I control more in depth, and everything went better.

As requested I added a property (disabled by default) to control the use of `withIgnoreSurroundingSpaces` and I had to rebase the commits or else some deps wouldn't be found anymore.
Oh my bad, for the last build error, I'm just dumb. I fix it immediately.
Any news ?
Reviewing
Looks like the github actions passed and I tested this out with a cluster and functionally appears working. +1 will merge.

I created a test class to measure the performance before and after the change. The source code of the test is available here:
https://gist.github.com/pgyori/5fa9499182d544f12ce2e5deeeba6d00
![AvroRecordReader performance](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63872658/119874424-e022bc00-bf25-11eb-88ae-bb4c1eeeb018.png)
Attached the results of my measurements before and after the fix. In my tests execution time increased by 6%-15%. I did not experience any change in memory consumption.

[UpdateRecord_field_removal.xml.zip](https://github.com/apache/nifi/files/6593186/UpdateRecord_field_removal.xml.zip)

At this point the PR is a draft.
NiFi Record handling has been enhanced to support the removal of fields.
At this point it supports:
 - removal of fields from records
 - removal of fields from nested records (deep structures are handled)
 - removal of fields from schemas when actual data is not present in the record
 - only the handling of primitive types and type RECORD.

Not yet supported:
 - the handling of the following types: MAP, CHOICE, ARRAY, ENUM.
 
The way field removal is triggered will be changed. Currently in UpdateRecord, a new dynamic property needs to be added, the name of the property should be the RecordPath to the field that needs to be removed and the value should be marked empty. Also, Replacement Value Strategy needs to be set to Record Path Value.

The unit tests have not yet been pushed. Those will arrive in a future commit.

Attached a flow template that can be used for testing.
Closing due to discussion here: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-8290
